_exec_summary.SummaryText:
CHS INC.  

CHS McPherson Refinery Inc. (CHS MRI)

McPHERSON, KANSAS

RISK MANAGEMENT PLAN EXECUTIVE SUMMARY



The purpose of this plan is to describe practices in place to mitigate hazards associated with the operation of the CHS McPherson Refinery Inc. (CHS MRI) located in McPherson, Kansas.  Information in this plan is available to the Local Emergency Planning Committee, outside emergency response groups, and other interested parties.



TABLE OF CONTENTS



1.  SUMMARY

2.  ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES

3.  DESCRIPTION OF THE STATIONARY SOURCES AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES

4.  HAZARD ASSESSMENT

5.  PREVENTION PROGRAM STEPS

      -Employee Participation

      -Process Safety Information

      -Process Hazard Analysis

      -Operating Procedures

      -Training

      -Contractors

      -Pre-startup Safety Reviews (PSSRs)

      -Mechanical Integrity

      -Safe Work Practices

      -Management of Change

      -Incident Investigation

      -Compliance Audits

6.  CHEMICAL RISK MANAGEMENT STEPS

7.  FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

8.  EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM INFORMATION

9.  PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY



1.0 SUMMARY



CHS MRI is committed to comply with all applicable health and safety regulations, conduct business in a manner which protects the people doing work under our control, and the general public from harm. This document outlines the Risk Management Plan in place at CHS MRI located at 1391 Iron Horse Road in McPherson, Kansas.  This Risk Management Plan is intended to comply with the requirements of EPA's Risk Management Program (40 CFR Part 68.) 

2.0 ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES



CHS MRI has a long-standing commitment to worker and public safety.  This commitment is demonstrated by the resources invested in accident prevention, training of personnel, and consideration of safety in the design, installation, operation, and maintenance of our facility.  Our policy is to imple

ment reasonable controls to prevent foreseeable releases of regulated substances.  However, if a release does occur, our personnel are trained to respond, control, and contain the release.



3.0 DESCRIPTION OF THE STATIONARY SOURCES AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES



CHS MRI operates a variety of processes to produce petroleum products from raw crude oil.  CHS MRI is capable of processing 115,000 barrels of crude oil per day and typically processes 11,000 barrels per day of natural gasoline. CHS MRI receives and transports petroleum products via trucks and pipelines and has a storage capacity of petroleum and refined products exceeding 1.5 million barrels in above ground tanks.



Some processes at CHS MRI have the potential to contain the following regulated substances in amounts greater than Risk Management Program Threshold Quantities:  butane, isobutane, propane, and hydrogen fluoride.   Additionally, many processes at CHS MRI contain mixtures of flammable substances in amounts exceeding the threshold quantity.  

 

4.0 HAZARD ASSESSMENT RESULTS



CHS MRI has completed all hazard assessments required under the Risk Management Program rules.   Details of the Hazard Assessment are included in the data submitted to the U.S. EPA's Central Data Exchange.



5.0 PREVENTION PROGRAM STEPS



The following is a summary of the general accident prevention program in place at CHS MRI. Because the processes at CHS MRI are regulated by the EPA Risk Management Program (RMP) regulation and OSHA Process Safety Management (PSM) standard, this summary addresses each of the OSHA PSM elements and describes the management system in place to implement the accident prevention program.



POL-42433-0062 PSM - Employee Participation 

In order to comply with OSHA's PSM Standard as referenced in 29 CFR 1910.119 (c) and EPA's RMP Rule referenced in 40 CFR 68.83, CHS MRI Employee Participation program outlines the method for assuring employee engagement and process for making documents associat

ed with the PSM elements available to CHS employees and contractor employees. CHS MRI is committed to including employees in the development and implementation of all aspects of the PSM program, including the Process Hazards Analysis.



Each process unit has one employee representative in the position of Special Project Operator.  This employee is responsible for writing and updating operating procedures, verifying P&ID drawings with engineers and interfacing between unit operators and management.  CHS MRI has a full time Union PSM/Safety Representative.  This employee is responsible for interfacing between union employees and management.    Other examples of employee participation include updating and compiling technical documents and chemical information, participating in the Union/Management Health and Safety Committee, participating as a member of a process hazard analysis (PHA) team, and participating as a member of a PSM Task Force.  



In addition to participating in incident reporting and investigation, employees have access to all information created as part of CHS MRI accident prevention program through several management system tools.  These management system tools allow employees to access numerous drawings, procedures, and safety information.

 

POL-42433-0063 PSM - Process Safety Information 

In order to comply with OSHA's PSM Standard as referenced in 29 CFR 1910.119 (d) and EPA's RMP Rule referenced in 40 CFR 68.65, CHS MRI is committed to gathering and updating data and information on all units in a timely manner. Maintaining complete and accurate information regarding refining process, chemicals, technology and equipment, and availability of this information to employees, is essential in assuring the process units are operated and maintained safely and reliably.



Chemical-specific information, including exposure hazards and emergency response/exposure treatment considerations, is provided in safety data sheets (SDSs).  This information is sup

plemented by documents that specifically address known corrosion concerns and any known hazards associated with the inadvertent mixing of chemicals.  For specific process areas, CHS MRI has documented safety-related limits for specific process parameters (e.g., temperature, level, composition).  CHS MRI assures that the process is maintained within these limits using process controls and monitoring instruments, highly trained personnel, and protective instrument systems (e.g., automated shutdown systems).



In addition, CHS MRI maintains numerous mechanical documents that provide information about the design and construction of process equipment.  This information includes materials of construction, design pressure and temperature ratings, electrical rating of equipment, etc.  This information, in combination with written procedures and trained personnel, provides a basis for establishing inspection and maintenance activities, as well as for evaluating proposed process and facility changes to assure that safety features in the process are not compromised.



Much of this information is available through the various management system tools that can be accessed from computers in the Refinery, maintenance shop and administrative offices.  Employees can obtain additional information not found on these management system tools through their supervisor and engineering department.





POL-42433-0064 PSM - Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) 

In order to comply with OSHA's PSM Standard as referenced in 29 CFR 1910.119 (e) and EPA's RMP Rule referenced in 40 CFR 68.67, CHS MRI developed a policy to provide guidance on the successful completion of the required PHA's and revalidation thereof at CHS MRI.



CHS MRI has a comprehensive program to help assure that hazards associated with the various processes are identified and controlled.  Within this program, each process is systematically examined to identify hazards and assure that adequate controls are in place to manage these h

azards.



CHS MRI primarily uses the hazard and operability (HAZOP) analysis technique to perform these evaluations.  HAZOP analysis is recognized as one of the most systematic and thorough hazard evaluation technique.  The analysis is conducted by a cross functional team made up of at least operations, process engineering, and PSM or Safety personnel.  This team identifies and evaluates hazards of the process as well as accident prevention and mitigation measure and makes suggestions for additional prevention and/or mitigation measures when the team believes such measures are necessary.



POL-42433-0065 PSM - Operating Procedures 

In order to comply with OSHA's PSM Standard as referenced in 29 CFR 1910.119 (f) and EPA's RMP Rule referenced in 40 CFR 68.69, CHS MRI Operating Procedure program assures that written procedures are developed, implemented and maintained. These written procedures provide clear instructions for safely conducting activities in any process that produces or uses highly hazardous chemicals. Written procedures are the foundation for making informed process-related decisions that maximize unit efficiency and assures process safety.



CHS MRI maintains written procedures that address various modes of process operations, such as unit startup, normal operations, temporary operations, emergency shutdown, normal shutdown, and initial startup of a new process.  These procedures can be used as a reference by experienced operators and provide a basis for consistent training of new operators.  These procedures are periodically reviewed and annually certified as current and accurate.  The procedures are maintained current and accurate by revising them as necessary to reflect changes made through the management of change process.



Written operating procedures are readily available to employees through a document control management system tool.



POL-42433-0066 PSM - Training 

In order to comply with OSHA's PSM Standard as referenced in 29 CFR 1910.

119 (g) and EPA's RMP Rule referenced in 40 CFR 68.71, CHS MRI strives to assure contractors are knowledgeable of the hazards related to their work and the process, and CHS MRI employees involved in operating or maintaining a covered process are knowledgeable in the processes that use or produce highly hazardous chemicals.



In support of the written procedures for process operations, CHS MRI implemented a comprehensive training program for all employees involved in operating a process.  New employees receive basic training in Refinery operations.  After successfully completing this training, a new operator is paired with a senior operator to learn process-specific duties and tasks.  After operators demonstrate (i.e., through tests and/or skills demonstration) having adequate knowledge to perform the duties and tasks in a safe manner on their own, they can work independently.  In addition, all operators periodically receive refresher training on the operating procedures to assure that their skills and knowledge are maintained at an acceptable level.  This refresher training is conducted at least every 3 years.  This training is documented for each operator, including the means used to verify that the operator understood the training.



POL-42433-0067 PSM - Contractors 

In order to comply with OSHA's PSM Standard as referenced in 29 CFR 1910.119 (h) and EPA's RMP Rule referenced in 40 CFR 68.87, CHS MRI Inc. establishes new criteria in evaluating, choosing and communicating with contractors. These criteria pertain only to contractors whose work involves them directly or indirectly with covered process equipment and units. It does not apply to contractors providing incidental services which do not influence process safety.



CHS MRI uses contractors to supplement its work force during periods of increased maintenance or construction activities.  Because some contractors work on or near process equipment, CHS MRI has procedures in place to assure that contractors p

erform their work in a safe manner, have the appropriate knowledge and skills, are aware of the hazards in their workplace, understand what they should do in the event of an emergency, understand and follow site safety rules, and inform Refinery personnel of any hazards that they find during their work.  This is accomplished by providing contractors with a process overview, information about safety and health hazards, emergency response plan requirements, and safe work practices prior to their work beginning.  In addition, CHS MRI evaluates contractor safety programs and performance during the selection of a contractor.  Refinery personnel periodically monitor contractor performance to assure that contractors are fulfilling their safety obligations.





POL-42433-0068 PSM - Pre-startup Safety Reviews (PSSRs)

In order to comply with OSHA's PSM Standard as referenced in 29 CFR 1910.119 (i) and EPA's RMP Rule referenced in 40 CFR 68.77, CHS MRI conducts PSSRs prior to introducing highly hazardous chemicals into a new process or process modified enough to require a change in the Process Safety Information (PSI).



CHS MRI conducts a PSSR for any new facility or facility modification that requires a change in the process safety information.  The purpose of the PSSR is to assure that safety features, procedures, personnel, and the equipment are appropriately prepared for startup prior to placing the equipment into service.  This review provides one additional check to assure construction is in accordance with the design specifications and that all supporting systems are operationally ready.  The PSSR review team uses checklists to verify all aspects of readiness.  A PSSR involves field verification of the construction and serves a quality assurance function by requiring verification that accident prevention program requirements are properly implemented.



POL-42433-0069 PSM - Mechanical Integrity 

In order to comply with OSHA's PSM Standard as referenced in 29 CFR 19

10.119 (j) and EPA's RMP Rule referenced in 40 CFR 68.73, CHS MRI is committed to the systematic implementation of activities, such as inspections and tests necessary to assure that equipment and systems will be suitable for its intended application throughout its life. Mechanical integrity is imperative for safe and reliable operation of the refinery, and the commitment by the CHS MRI to these goals is a cooperative effort of all employees.



CHS MRI has established practices and procedures to maintain pressure vessels, piping systems, relief and vent systems, controls, pumps and compressors and emergency shutdown systems in a safe operating condition.  The basic aspects of this program include identification and categorization of process equipment, performing inspections and tests of process equipment, correcting identified deficiencies, applying quality assurance measures and documentation of these steps.  In combination, these activities form a system that maintains the mechanical integrity of the process equipment.



Inspections and tests are performed to help assure that equipment functions as intended, and to verify that equipment is within acceptable limits (e.g., adequate wall thickness for pressure vessels) and meets the applicable regulatory codes and standards.  If a deficiency is identified, corrections will be made before placing the equipment back into service (if possible), or a Management of Change (MOC) team will review the use of the equipment and determine what actions are necessary to assure the safe operation of the equipment.



Training requirements for maintaining and inspecting equipment including an overview of the process and its hazards, and the procedures applicable to employees' work to assure the work is performed in a safe manner.



Another integral part of the mechanical integrity program is quality assurance.  CHS MRI incorporates quality assurance measures into equipment purchases and repairs.  This helps assure that new equipm

ent is suitable for its intended use and that proper materials and spare parts are used when repairs are made.



Safe Work Practices 

CHS MRI has standing safe work practices in place to help assure worker and process safety.  Examples of these include control of the entry/presence/exit of support personnel, lockout/tagout procedure to assure isolation of energy sources for equipment undergoing maintenance, procedure for safe removal of hazardous materials before process piping or equipment is opened, permit and procedure to control spark-producing activities (i.e., hot work), and permit and procedure to assure that adequate precautions are in place before entry into a confined space.  These procedures (and others), along with training of affected personnel, form a system to help assure that operations and maintenance activities are performed safely.

In support of this effort, CHS MRI implemented a safe work permit in 2017. The intent of the Safe Work Permit is to assure communication between all parties regarding the safety of the job site, so a mutual understanding is developed between the parties involved on the safe manner in which to conduct the work.



POL-42433-0071 PSM - Management of Change 

In order to comply with OSHA's PSM Standard as referenced in 29 CFR 1910.119 (l) and EPA's RMP Rule referenced in 40 CFR 68.75, CHS MRI Management of Change program outlines the items CHS MRI must address prior to any change (except for "replacement in kind") to process chemicals, technology, equipment, and procedures, and changes to facilities that affect a covered process. CHS MRI reserves the right to use the MOC program at our discretion for purposes not associated with PSM covered processes.



CHS MRI has a comprehensive system to manage changes to processes.  This system required that changes to items such as process equipment, chemicals, technology (including process operating conditions), procedures, and other facility changes be properly reviewed and auth

orized before being implemented.  Changes are reviewed to assure that adequate controls are in place to manage any new hazards and verify that existing controls have not been compromised by the change.  Affected chemical hazard information, process operating limits, and equipment information, as well as procedures, are updated to incorporate these changes.  In addition, operating and maintenance personnel are provided any necessary training on the change.



POL-42433-0072 PSM - Incident Investigation 

In order to comply with OSHA's PSM Standard as referenced in 29 CFR 1910.119 (m) and EPA's RMP Rule referenced in 40 CFR 68.81, CHS MRI Inc. assures incidents that result in, or could reasonably have resulted in, an uncontrolled release of toxic materials, fires, explosions, significant equipment damage, personnel injuries, adverse environmental effects or affects to the general public are investigated to identify root causes that contributed to the incident and take corrective action(s) in an effort to prevent recurrence of similar or systemic incidents.



POL-42433-0074 PSM - Compliance Audits 

In order to comply with OSHA's PSM Standard as referenced in 29 CFR 1910.119 (o) and EPA's RMP Rule referenced in 40 CFR 68.79, CHS MRI completes on a three-year cycle a compliance audit that serves as a self-audit to measure the overall effectiveness of the PSM and RMP programs. The audits assure procedures and practices developed under PSM and RMP are adequate, understood and being followed. Exceptions are documented and corrective action plans developed, tracked and completed.



6.0 CHEMICAL RISK MANAGEMENT STEPS



The processes at CHS MRI have hazards that are managed to assure continued safe operation.  The accident prevention program summarized previously is applied to all Program 3 EPA RMP-covered processes at CHS MRI.  Collectively, these prevention program activities help prevent potential accident scenarios that could be caused by equipment failures and/or huma

n errors.



In addition to the accident prevention program activities, CHS MRI has safety features on many units to help contain/control a release, quickly detect a release, reduce the consequences of (mitigate) a release.  The following types of safety features are used in various processes:



Release Detection

1.  Hydrocarbon (crude oil products) detectors with alarms

2.  Hydrogen Fluoride and Hydrogen Sulfide detectors with alarms

3.  Process instrumentation with alarms

4.  Twenty-four hour/day monitoring or processes by process unit operators.



Release Containment/Control

1.  Process relief valves that discharge to a flare where releases are incinerated

2.  Valves to permit isolation of the process (manual and/or automated)

3.  Automated shutdown systems for specific process parameters (e.g., high level, high temperature)

4.  Vessels to permit partial removal of the process inventory in the event of a release

5.  Curbing or diking to contain liquid releases

6.  Redundant equipment and instrumentation (e.g., uninterruptible power supply for process control system, backup firewater pump)

7.  Atmospheric relief devices



Release and Fire Mitigation

1.  Refinery fire water system

      -Diesel driven fire water pumps

      -Fire hydrants with permanently mounted water monitors throughout Refinery

      -Firefighting foam stations

2.  Fixed deluge systems for specific process equipment

3.  Trained emergency response teams (24-hour on call)

      -Emergency Response Team 

      -Rescue Team

      -Hazardous Materials Team

      -Emergency Medical Team

4.  Emergency Response Equipment

      -Three firefighting pumper trucks

      -Hazardous materials response trailer

      -Specialized firefighting foam equipment

     -6250gpm Industrial Super Pumper



     -2000-gallon Foam Tender



     -2000-gpm Quick Attack



     -Type -6 Brush Truck



5.  Personal protective equipment for Refinery personnel



HF Alkylation Unit Active Mitigatio

n Equipment

1.  Closed circuit unit television system monitored 24 hours/day by operators

2.  Remote operated valves for containment of hydrogen fluoride in event of leak

3.  Elevated deluge monitors around hydrogen fluoride area

4.  Deluge system on hydrogen fluoride pumps and gauge glasses

5.  Fire hydrant mounted monitors around hydrogen fluoride storage

6.  Administrative control to minimize amount of hydrogen fluoride in storage



Other Items to Prevent or Mitigate a Release/Fire

1.  Mutual aid agreements with local emergency agencies

2.  Routine training for Emergency Response Teams

      -Classroom training

      -Field training

3.  Employees are trained on emergency response duties through:

      -Classroom training

      -Field training

      -Computer based training

4.  Refinery emergency notification systems

      -Refinery emergency outdoor warning system

      -Pager system for process units and emergency personnel

      -Multi-channel employee handheld radio system

      -Refinery emergency telephone number answered by 24-hour dispatch

5.  Preventive maintenance program for Refinery process equipment

6.  Scheduled maintenance and testing of emergency equipment and systems

7.  Onsite Refinery engineering staff to assure equipment and processes complies with latest specifications

8.  Scheduled Refinery shut down for maintenance (4 or 5 year schedule)

9.  Full time Environment, Health and Safety staff





7.0 FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY



During the last five years, no accidents have occurred involving a release of regulated substances.  



8.0 EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM INFORMATION



CHS MRI maintains a written emergency response plan to assure a coordinated and timely response to chemical releases, fires, explosions, natural disasters as well as other emergencies.  This type of response is necessary to protect public and worker safety as well as the environment.  Items covered in the plan include emergency notification and re

sponse of employees, notification of local emergency response agencies and the public, first-aid and emergency medical care, evacuation plans and routes, accounting of personnel after an evacuation, emergency equipment list, inspection, testing and maintenance of emergency equipment, and employee emergency plan training requirements.  The emergency response program is reviewed annually and updated as needed.  The overall emergency response program for CHS MRI is coordinated with the McPherson County Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC).  This committee is comprised of local emergency response officials, industry representatives and other concerned citizens.  CHS MRI has a representative on this committee.



CHS MRI has the capability to communicate with McPherson County Emergency Management officials and emergency response organizations by telephone and handheld radios.  This provides a means of notifying the public of an incident, if necessary, as well as facilitating quick response to an incident.  In addition to participating in LEPC meetings, CHS MRI conducts periodic emergency drills that involve the LEPC and emergency response organizations.  The Refinery provides refresher training to local emergency responders regarding the hazards of regulated substances in the Refinery.





9.0 PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY



CHS MRI is constantly looking for ways to improve safety and decrease possible exposure to chemicals.   Regular audits, safety information reviews and process hazard analyses provide the facility with a systematic approach to identify changes to improve safety, and to track and document the implementation of such changes.   



CHS MRI continues to work on development of a Safety Culture Change program.   A Union/Management Guidance team provides the leadership for this program.  Six Grass Roots employee directed teams have been started and are working on safety projects throughout the facility.



CHS MRI continues to improve four key are

as: infrastructure, response equipment, training, and document control. 



CHS MRI routinely reviews fire water demands. As a result, CHS MRI continuously strives to improve underground piping, hydrant manifold configurations, and fire water supply. CHS MRI is currently completing the installation of a new fire water tank and additional fire pumps. On a parallel path, CHS MRI invested in a 3000 gpm submersible pump to augment fire water supply. The submersible pump enables CHS MRI to use static water sources, if necessary. CHS MRI routinely reviews deluge systems throughout the facility and upgrades are planned and completed as needed.  



CHS MRI routinely reviews response equipment. As a result, CHS MRI continuously strives to improve response equipment capability. CHS MRI made multiple investments to enhance water flow capability and increased/efficient response. These investments include: 

o    6250 gpm Industrial Super Pumper

o    2000 - gallon Foam Tender

o    2000 gpm Quick Attack

o    Type 6 Brush Truck

o    6000 feet of 7.25-inch fire hose

o    (6) ground and elevated portable fire monitors

o    6000 gallons AFFF-AR 1%x3% Firefighting Foam

o    2500 gallons Vapor Suppression Foam



CHS MRI routinely reviews response training. As a result, CHS MRI continuously strives to improve ERT training. In February 2019, the facility received Fire Service Training Accreditation from JOIFF. This accreditation was received in conjunction with the completion of a 4-million-dollar fire training facility that was built by CHS MRI. The combination of the accreditation and new training facility allows for internationally recognized training programs to be provided to CHS MRI ERT members. Since February 2019, courses and certifications have been given in the following areas:

o    Industrial Firefighting

o    Incident Command

o    Driver/Operator

o    HAZMAT Awareness

o    HAZMAT Operations



CHS MRI continues to leverage existing and recently developed and implemented management system tools to enh

ance documentation of key Health, Safety, PSM, and Emergency Response activities following the traditional Plan, Do, Check, Act philosophy.



CHS MRI continuously reviews and revises a 5-year plan focusing on fire apparatus and equipment enhancements.
